Old Saxon <span class="italic">kasi</span>, Old High German <span class="italic">chasi</span>, German <span class="italic">Käse</span>, Middle Dutch <span class="italic">case</span>, Dutch <span class="italic">kaas</span>), from Latin <span class="italic">caseus</span> "cheese" (source of Italian <span class="italic">cacio</span>, Spanish <span class="italic">queso</span>, Irish <span class="italic">caise</span>, Welsh <span class="italic">caws</span>).</p><p class="css-mgww5h ehevz041">Of unknown origin; perhaps from a PIE root <span class="italic">*kwat-</span> "to ferment, become sour" (cf. Prakrit <span class="italic">chasi</span> "buttermilk;" Old Church Slavonic <span class="italic">kvasu</span> "leaven; fermented drink," <span class="italic">kyselu</span> "sour," <span class="italic">-kyseti</span> "to turn sour;" Czech <span class="italic">kysati</span> "to turn sour, rot;" Sanskrit <span class="italic">kvathati</span> "boils, seethes;" Gothic <span class="italic">hwaþjan</span> "foam"). Also cf. <a href="/browse/fromage" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">fromage</a>. Old Norse <span class="italic">ostr</span>, Danish <span class="italic">ost</span>, Swedish <span class="italic">ost</span> are related to Latin <span class="italic">ius</span> "broth, sauce, juice."</p><p class="css-mgww5h ehevz041">Earliest references would be to compressed curds of milk used as food; pressed or molded cheeses with rinds are 14c. Transferred to other cheese-like substances by 1530s. As a photographer's word to make subjects hold a smile, it is attested from 1930, but in a reminiscence of schoolboy days, which suggests an earlier use. Probably for the forced smile involved in making the <span class="italic">-ee-</span> sound. <span class="italic">Green cheese</span> is that newly made; the notion that the moon is made of green cheese as a type of a ridiculous assertion is from 1520s. To <span class="italic">make cheeses</span> was a schoolgirls' amusement (1835) of wheeling rapidly so one's petticoats blew out in a circle then dropping down so they came to rest inflated and resembling a wheel of cheese; hence, used figuratively for "a deep curtsey."</p></section><div class="css-grsm00 eleb6uy1"><div class="css-6416ii eleb6uy2">Show More</div></div></div></div></section><section class="css-i3pbo e8i5ajd0"><div><div class="css-xojh1k eleb6uy0"><section class="css-k59p8l ehevz040"><h3 class="css-utybho ehevz045">n.2</h3><p class="css-mgww5h ehevz041">"the proper thing," from Urdu <span class="italic">chiz</span> "a thing," from Persian <span class="italic">chiz</span>, from Old Persian <span class="italic">*ciš-ciy</span> "something," from PIE pronomial stem <span class="italic">*kwo-</span> (see <a href="/browse/who" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">who</a>). Picked up by British in India by 1818 and used in the sense of "a big thing" (especially in the phrase <span class="italic">the real chiz</span>).</p><p class="css-mgww5h ehevz041">This perhaps is behind the expression <span class="italic">big cheese</span> "important person" (1914), but that is American English in origin and likely rather belongs to <a href="/browse/cheese" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">cheese</a> (n.1). To <span class="italic">cut a big cheese</span> as a figurative expression for "look important" is recorded from 1915, and overlarge wheels of cheese, especially from Wisconsin, were commonly displayed 19c. as publicity stunts by retailers, etc. </p><style data-emotion-css="1egb0pc">.css-1egb0pc{padding:10px 20px;margin:0 0 20px;border-left:5px solid #e6e6e7;}</style><blockquote class="css-1egb0pc ehevz042"> The cheese will be on exhibition at the National Dairy Show at Chicago next week. President Taft will visit the show the morning of Monday, October thirtieth, and after his address he will be invited to cut the big cheese, which will then be distributed in small lots to visitors at the show. ["The Country Gentleman," Oct. 28, 1911] </blockquote></section><div class="css-grsm00 eleb6uy1"><div class="css-6416ii eleb6uy2">Show More</div></div></div></div></section><section class="css-i3pbo e8i5ajd0"><div><div class="css-xojh1k eleb6uy0"><section class="css-k59p8l ehevz040"><h3 class="css-utybho ehevz045">v.</h3><p class="css-mgww5h ehevz041">"stop (what one is doing), run off," 1812, thieves' slang, of uncertain origin. Meaning "to smile" is from 1930 (see <a href="/browse/cheese" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">cheese</a> (n.1)). For meaning "to annoy," see <a href="/browse/cheesed" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">cheesed</a>. </p><blockquote class="css-1egb0pc ehevz042"> CHEESE IT. Be silent, be quiet, don't do it. Cheese it, the coves are fly; be silent, the people understand our discourse. ["Dictionary of Buckish Slang, University Wit, and Pickpocket Eloquence," London, 1811] </blockquote></section><div class="css-grsm00 eleb6uy1"><div class="css-6416ii eleb6uy2">Show More</div></div></div></div></section><div class="css-1yphgw4 ejtq9h60">Online Etymology Dictionary, © 2010 Douglas Harper</div><hr class="css-11r0tj9 etjs7ll0"/></section><section class="css-i3pbo e8i5ajd0"><h2 class="css-1q5i0w0 e1cxe2lc0">Idioms and Phrases with <!-- -->cheese</h2><style data-emotion-css="e1plaw">.css-e1plaw{font-weight:normal;word-break:break-word;display:inline-block;font-size:22px;margin:0 15px 10px 0;line-height:1.7;}@media (max-width:768px){.css-e1plaw{font-size:18px;margin:0 10px 10px 0;}}</style><h1 class="css-e1plaw e1rg2mtf5">cheese</h1><section class="css-i3pbo e8i5ajd0"><div><div class="css-xojh1k eleb6uy0"><section class="css-k59p8l ehevz040"><p class="css-mgww5h ehevz041">In addition to the idioms beginning with <span class="bold">cheese</span></p><style data-emotion-css="omsch0">.css-omsch0{list-style:none;-webkit-columns:2;columns:2;margin-bottom:17px;}</style><ul class="css-omsch0 ehevz044"><li><a href="/browse/cheesed off" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">cheesed off</a></li><li><a href="/browse/cheese it" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">cheese it</a></li></ul><p class="css-mgww5h ehevz041">also see: </p><ul class="css-omsch0 ehevz044"><li><a href="/browse/big cheese" class="luna-xref" data-linkid="nn1ov4">big cheese</a></li></ul></section><div class="css-grsm00 eleb6uy1"><div class="css-6416ii eleb6uy2">Show More</div></div></div></div></section><div class="css-1yphgw4 ejtq9h60">The American Heritage® Idioms Dictionary

Prakrit \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Echasi\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"buttermilk;\" Old Church Slavonic \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Ekvasu\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"leaven; fermented drink,\" \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Ekyselu\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"sour,\" \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003E-kyseti\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"to turn sour;\" Czech \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Ekysati\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"to turn sour, rot;\" Sanskrit \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Ekvathati\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"boils, seethes;\" Gothic \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Ehwaþjan\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"foam\"). Also cf. \u003Ca href=\"\u002Fbrowse\u002Ffromage\" class=\"luna-xref\" data-linkid=\"nn1ov4\"\u003Efromage\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Old Norse \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Eostr\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, Danish \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Eost\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, Swedish \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Eost\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E are related to Latin \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Eius\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"broth, sauce, juice.\""},{"type":"paragraph","content":"Earliest references would be to compressed curds of milk used as food; pressed or molded cheeses with rinds are 14c. Transferred to other cheese-like substances by 1530s. As a photographer's word to make subjects hold a smile, it is attested from 1930, but in a reminiscence of schoolboy days, which suggests an earlier use. Probably for the forced smile involved in making the \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003E-ee-\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E sound. \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003EGreen cheese\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E is that newly made; the notion that the moon is made of green cheese as a type of a ridiculous assertion is from 1520s. To \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Emake cheeses\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E was a schoolgirls' amusement (1835) of wheeling rapidly so one's petticoats blew out in a circle then dropping down so they came to rest inflated and resembling a wheel of cheese; hence, used figuratively for \"a deep curtsey.\""}]}],"supplementaryNotes":[]},{"id":"45485","type":"normal","entry":"cheese","entrySyllabified":null,"entryVariants":[],"homograph":null,"pronunciation":null,"predefinitionContent":null,"contentBlocks":[{"title":"(n.2)","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":"\"the proper thing,\" from Urdu \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Echiz\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"a thing,\" from Persian \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Echiz\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, from Old Persian \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003E*ciš-ciy\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"something,\" from PIE pronomial stem \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003E*kwo-\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E (see \u003Ca href=\"\u002Fbrowse\u002Fwho\" class=\"luna-xref\" data-linkid=\"nn1ov4\"\u003Ewho\u003C\u002Fa\u003E). Picked up by British in India by 1818 and used in the sense of \"a big thing\" (especially in the phrase \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Ethe real chiz\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E)."},{"type":"paragraph","content":"This perhaps is behind the expression \u003Cspan class=\"italic\"\u003Ebig cheese\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \"important person\" (1914), but that is American English in origin and likely rather belongs to \u003Ca href=\"\u002Fbrowse\u002Fcheese\" class=\"luna-xref\" data-linkid=\"nn1ov4\"\u003Echeese\u003C\u002Fa\u003E (n.1). The assumption apparently is because Pierre Lallement, employee of a French carriage works, improved Macmillan's 1839 pedal velocipede in 1865 and took the invention to America.         googletag.cmd.push(function() {
          googletag.slots[slot.placement] = googletag.defineSlot(slot.code, slot.sizes, slot.placement).addService(googletag.pubads());
          for (var target in slot.targeting) {
            if (slot.targeting.hasOwnProperty(target)) {
              googletag.slots[slot.placement].setTargeting(target, slot.targeting[target]);
            }
          }
        });
      });
    }

    googletag.cmd.push(function() {
      googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();
      googletag.enableServices();
    });

Slang sense of "head" is from 1630s. Extended sense of "obstruction" is first recorded 1640s. In cricket from 1825; in U.S. football from 1912. The meaning in <span class="italic">city block</span> is 1796, from the notion of a "compact mass" of buildings; slang meaning "fashionable promenade" is 1869. </p><style data-emotion-css="1egb0pc">.css-1egb0pc{padding:10px 20px;margin:0 0 20px;border-left:5px solid #e6e6e7;}</style><blockquote class="css-1egb0pc ehevz042"> BLOCK.
